comments.author: molesmoke
comments.body: That's an interesting point - there's nothing on the dotnet side at build time that requires an OS version-specific TFM. However, the native DLL for 3.119 is built against DX12, so it won't run on on the TFM default OS version (7.0). On that basis, specifying net8.0-windows10.0.19041 seems reasonable (though I note that MS did publish a Win 7 compatibility package for DX12). The downstream package currently also wouldn't work as expected for net8.0-windows (i.e. Windows 7.0).

comments.author: xincheng213618
comments.body:
I have also encountered similar issues when referencing both [LiveChartsCore.SkiaSharpView.WPF](https://www.nuget.org/packages/LiveChartsCore.SkiaSharpView.WPF/) and [ScottPlot.WPF](https://www.nuget.org/packages/ScottPlot.WPF/). When I tried to upgrade LiveCharts, I ran into versioning problems.

Although I'm using the default .NET 7.0, both packages work fine on Windows 11. However, enforcing strict version requirements creates another problem: new projects with default NuGet settings may not find my package. To maximize compatibility, there seem to be two options: use the same version as ScottPlot (2.88.9) or upgrade like LiveCharts and let downstream users handle the versioning.

But honestly, this doesn't seem ideal. The 7.0 requirement is just a minimum; it doesn't mean the package only works on Windows 7. This is more of a .NET ecosystem issue—strict versioning mostly affects UWP and WinUI, which are now mostly deprecated.

Given this, perhaps it's better to remove the strict version limitation to encourage a more flexible and thriving ecosystem. Of course, this is just my perspective. I'm interested to hear your thoughts on this as well.

comments.author: molesmoke
comments.body:
Well, what I'm saying is that SkiaSharp 3.119 won't run on Windows 7, it'll only run on Windows 10 and later: #3267

The OS version in the TFM is supposed to indicate which APIs the app/library compiles against. AFAIK, the SkiaSharp bindings themselves don't use any APIs from 10.0.19041 at build time - but it does have a transitive build dependency because of the native Skia part being built against DX12.

comments.author: xincheng213618
comments.body: So in the next version, can we remove the mandatory requirement for 10.0.19041, and instead prompt users that we no longer support it, thereby providing support for net8.0-windows instead of net8.0-windows10.0.19041, so that we can download it in nuget
